q: What are the different types of radiotherapy?
a: The different types of radiotherapy include external radiotherapy, radiotherapy implants (brachytherapy), radiotherapy injections or capsules (radioisotope therapy), and intrabeam radiotherapy.

q: What are the side effects of radiotherapy?
a: Common side effects of radiotherapy include sore skin, fatigue, hair loss, nausea, loss of appetite, sore mouth, and diarrhea. These side effects can usually be treated or prevented.

q: When is radiotherapy used?
a: Radiotherapy can be used in the early stages of cancer, after it has spread, to try to cure the cancer, make other treatments more effective, reduce the risk of the cancer coming back after surgery, or provide palliative relief from symptoms.

q: How is external radiotherapy given?
a: External radiotherapy involves using a machine to aim beams of radiation at the cancer. It is usually given in a hospital setting, and the patient can usually go home soon after the treatment.

q: Can radiotherapy make you radioactive?
a: External radiotherapy does not make you radioactive, as the radiation passes through your body. However, radiation from implants or injections may stay in your body for a few days, requiring precautions and limited contact with others.

q: What are the purposes of curative radiotherapy?
a: Curative radiotherapy aims to completely cure the cancer by using radiation to kill cancer cells. It is typically used in the early stages of cancer.

q: How can radiotherapy be combined with other treatments?
a: Radiotherapy can be combined with chemotherapy or used before surgery to make the other treatments more effective. This is known as neo-adjuvant radiotherapy.

q: What is the role of adjuvant radiotherapy?
a: Adjuvant radiotherapy is used after surgery to reduce the risk of the cancer coming back. It is given to patients who may still have cancer cells remaining in the body.

q: What is the purpose of palliative radiotherapy?
a: Palliative radiotherapy is used to relieve symptoms when a cure for the cancer is not possible. It aims to improve the patient's quality of life and alleviate pain or discomfort.

q: Is intrabeam radiotherapy available at all hospitals?
